questions.text: Approximately how many polymerase chain reaction (PCR) products are produced from a single template DNA molecule in a PCR reaction that continues for 30 cycles?
questions.solution:
A PCR reaction that continues for 30 cycles will produce approximately 1 billion PCR products from a single template DNA molecule.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a method of amplifying a target sequence of DNA. DNA sequences as short as 50 to 100 bp and as long as 10 kb can be amplified by PCR. The amplification is exponential.

  • 20 cycles provide amplification of 220 = 106  or 1 million copies
  • 30 cycles provide an amplification of 230 =109 or 1 billion copies

questions.text: A 3-week-old baby presented with 2 episodes of fits. On examination, repetitive movements as if the baby was boxing and bicycling were noticed. His urine had a sweetish odor and was positive for the dinitrophenylhydrazine test. Blood concentrations of which of the following amino acids is relatively higher in the baby?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a positive urine dinitrophenylhydrazine test is suggestive of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). The levels of leucine are higher than the other three amino acids.

MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex. This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids valine, leucine, isoleucine and alloisoleucine. These amino acids, particularly leucine and its metabolite accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain.

The affected child develops poor feeding and vomiting a few days after birth. There is a period of hypertonicity with a period of flaccidity in between. These appear as repetitive boxing and bicycling movements. The babies may also have hypoglycemia, but this is not corrected by the administration of glucose. The urine, sweat, and cerumen of the baby have a sweetish maple syrup-like odor.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Leucine levels are usually higher than isoleucine, valine, and alloisoleucine. Since the patient excretes ketoacids in the urine, the urine will be positive for the dinitrophenylhydrazine test.

Treatment involves controlled intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine. Very high levels of leucine are removed by hemodialysis.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text: An infant with abdominal distension, fever, and jaundice was brought to the pediatric OPD. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of an autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase was arrived at. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase in a child with abdominal distension, fever and jaundice is associated with Hepatorenal tyrosinemia (Type 1 tyrosinemia or tyrosinosis). It is the most common type of tyrosinemia. 

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 (Hepatorenal tyrosinemia):
    • Defective enzyme: Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase 
    • Inherited as an autosomal recessive trait
    • Clinical features: Liver failure, hypoglycemia, boiled cabbage odour in the urine, and mental retardation. 
  • Type 2 (Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome):
    • Defective enzyme: Tyrosine transaminase 
    • Clinical features: Palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions, photophobia, mental retardation are seen. 
  • Type 3 (Neonatal tyrosinemia): 
    • Defective enzyme: 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase 
    • Clinical features: Normal liver function, developmental delay, seizures and intermittent ataxia are seen.
  • Hawkinsuria
    • Defective enzyme: 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase 
    • Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait
    • Clinical features: Transient failure to thrive and metabolic acidosis in infancy

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with jaundice and tiredness. On investigation, his AST was 150 IU/L, ALT was 175 IU/L and bilirubin was 4.5mg/dl. Serum ceruloplasmin levels were found to be low. Which of the following minerals is used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
An adolescent with jaundice, elevated AST, ALT and low serum ceruloplasmin likely has Wilson’s disease. Zinc is used in the treatment of this condition.

Wilson’s disease is an autosomonal recessive disorder. It is charactered by mutations of the ATP7B gene, resulting in decreased biliary copper excretion and ceruloplasmin formation. The accumulation of copper leads to liver disease, hemolysis, a movement disorder neurologic disease, and/or psychiatric illness.

Elemental zinc is commonly used as a maintenance therapy along with chelating agents. Zinc acts by blocking the intestinal absorption of copper. It can also be used as first-line therapy in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old bodybuilder started a diet of raw eggs as a source of protein, following which he developed dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, and muscular pains. On investigation, he was diagnosed with a vitamin deficiency. Which of the following enzymes does not require this vitamin as a coenzyme?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of features like dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, and muscle pain developing in an individual on a raw egg diet is suggestive of biotin deficiency, and carbamoyl phosphate synthetase is the enzyme that is not dependent on biotin.

A protein called avidin is present in the egg white, which binds to biotin in the diet, making biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption. Avidin is heat labile, and boiling of the egg neutralizes its inhibitory activity. One molecule of avidin can bind with four molecules of biotin.

Biotin deficiency is rare, except in individuals on prolonged total parenteral nutrition and those consuming raw eggs. Individuals with a biotin deficiency may develop features such as dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, and hallucinations. Treatment is the administration of an injection of 100–300 mg biotin.

Biotin serves as a co-enzyme for several carboxylase enzymes:

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase
    • This enzyme adds CO2 to acetyl CoA, forming malonyl CoA.
    • It is the rate-limiting reaction in the biosynthesis of fatty acids
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
    • Pyruvate + CO2 +ATP → Oxaloacetate +ADP + Pi
    • It provides oxaloacetate, which is the catalyst for the TCA cycle and is an important enzyme in gluconeogenesis.
  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
    • Propionyl CoA +CO2 + ATP → Methyl malonyl CoA + ADP + Pi
  • Methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase

Biotin also plays a role in the regulation of the cell cycle.

Biotin-independent reactions:

  • Urea and pyrimidine synthesis, with carbamoyl phosphate synthetase as the stepping stone
  • Addition of CO2 to form C6 in the purine ring
  • Conversion of pyruvate to malate by malic enzyme

questions.text: Identify the components of the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing tool.
questions.solution:
The components of the CRISPR-9 gene-editing tool are guide RNA and Cas9 nuclease.

CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material. It uses guide RNA transcribed from CRISPR DNA (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Palindromic Repeats of DNA) and a Cas9 (CRISPR-associated protein 9) nuclease.

The guide RNA targets and binds to specific complementary sequences of DNA which are then cleaved by Cas9. Following cleavage of the targeted DNA sequence, the natural DNA repair process can be allowed to proceed or a new sequence can be inserted.

This technique can be used for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and modulation of gene transcription.

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna for the development of the CRISPR/ Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is found to be hypotonic, with a high forehead, large anterior fontanelle, markedly separated cranial sutures, and hepatomegaly. Further investigations confirmed a diagnosis of the cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome. Which of the following biochemical findings would not be seen in this case?

choices.text: Elevated levels of very long chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
In cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome or Zellweger syndrome, there is a decreased level of plasmalogens.

Zellweger syndrome is caused by mutations in the peroxins (PEX) family of genes. As a result of this, there is a defective transport of the proteins to the peroxisomes. It severely impairs the functions of peroxisomes, resulting in defective beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

The child presents with

  • Dysmorphic facial features like wide anterior fontanelles markedly separated cranial sutures, epicanthal folds, broad nasal bridge, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, etc.
  • Profound developmental delay, profound hypotonia with depressed deep tendon reflexes, neonatal seizures, and impaired hearing
  • Calcific stippling of the epiphyses
  • Renal cysts
  • Hepatomegaly

Biochemical findings will show:

  • Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, phytanic acid, and pipecolic acids
  • Abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
  • Marked reduction of plasmalogens
  • Elevated levels of plasma phytanic acid

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe, and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: A group of scientists is studying a protein. They electrophorese the protein and transfer it to a membrane. The proteins are visualized by tagging them to specific antibodies. This procedure is called:
questions.solution:
The above procedure depicts Western blot technique. This technique is used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized. 

Northern blot technique is used to detect RNAs. The RNAs are separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a membrane and bound to radiolabelled probes.

Southern blot technique is used to detect DNAs. In this technique, DNA is extracted from the cells and is cleaved into many fragments using a restriction enzyme. The resulting fragments are separated based on the size using electrophoresis. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane for analysis. The DNA fragment of interest is then identified using the specific DNA probe.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with complaints that the child does not crawl or sit, does not smile, and does not recognize the mother. During the examination, it is noted that the child has a very fair complexion, light color hair, smaller head circumference for age, growth, and developmental delay. The child has a mousey odor. Which of the following are used in the management of this condition?
  1. Pegvaliase
  2. Tyrosine restriction
  3. Large neutral amino acids
  4. Sapropterin dihydrochloride
  5. Taliglucerase alpha
questions.solution:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of phenylketonuria (PKU). Pegvaliase, large neutral amino acids, and sapropterin dihydrochloride are used in the management of this condition. Tyrosine supplementation is used, and not restriction.

Phenylketonuria commonly occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, PAH (classic phenylketonuria). Less commonly it can also occur due to a defect in the enzymes producing tetrahydrobiopterin. These defects result in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. The patient develops clinical features due to elevated levels of phenylalanine metabolites and decreased levels of tyrosine.

Clinical features 

  • Intellectual disability, developmental delay, microcephaly, and seizures- due to accumulation of phenylalanine metabolites and decreased tyrosine.
  • Fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes- Tyrosine is needed for the synthesis of melanin. Reduced levels of tyrosine lead to the decreased melanin synthesis.
  • The babies have a mousey odor due to the accumulation of phenylacetic acid.

Laboratory investigations that are useful in the diagnosis are

  • Blood levels of phenylalanine
  • Ferric chloride test
  • Guthrie test
  • Tandem mass spectrometry

Management

A diet low in phenylalanine and supplementation of tyrosine can prevent the mental retardation of PKU. The blood levels of phenylalanine are maintained between 2 and 6 mg/dL.

Administration of large neutral amino acid supplementation are useful. Tyrosine, tryptophan, leucine, isoleucine, valine, methionine, histidine, and phenylalanine share the same transporter for transport through intestinal membrane and blood-brain barrier. Hence, these amino acids compete and prevent the transport of phenylalanine.

Sapropterin is a synthetic form of BH4, which acts as a cofactor in patients with residual PAH activity. 

Pegvaliase is a phenylalanine ammonia-lyase (PAL), that converts phenylalanine to ammonia and trans-cinnamic acid.

Eliglustat, taliglucerase alpha, velaglucerase alpha, imiglucarase, miglustat are approved by FDA for Gaucher's disease treatment.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

questions.text: A patient was advised to take green leafy vegetables as a natural dietary source of vitamin K. Which is the compound that acts as the source of vitamin K in these vegetables?
questions.solution:
The normal dietary source of vitamin K is phylloquinone or vitamin K1, found in green leafy vegetables.

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin and its deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

Three compounds have the biological activity of vitamin K:

  • Phylloquinone (Vitamin K1) is the normal dietary source of Vitamin K that is found in green leafy vegetables.
  • Menaquinone (Vitamin K2) is synthesized by intestinal bacteria.
  • Menadione (Vitamin K3) and menadiol diacetate are synthetic compounds that are metabolized to phylloquinone.

questions.text: A child is brought to the doctor with severe agonizing, burning pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities. On examination, he also has telangiectatic skin lesions, particularly between the umbilicus and knees. The ophthalmic examination also reveals corneal opacity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Fabry disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid metabolism because of deficient activity of α-galactosidase A enzyme. This enzyme deficiency leads to accumulations of neutral glycosphingolipids, primarily globotriaosylceramide, especially in the plasma and lysosomes of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells, cardiac myocytes, and renal podocytes. The features of Fabry disease include:

  • Angiokeratomas- telangiectatic skin lesions characteristically seen densest between the umbilicus and knees called the bathing trunk area
  • Hypohidrosis - decreased sweating
  • Corneal and lenticular opacities (Cornea verticillata)
  • Painful acroparesthesias 
  • Fabry crises - severe agonizing pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities
  • Urinary examination shows lipid inclusions with birefringent maltese cross

 Given below is the image of cornea verticillata.

Other options

Option B- Niemann-Pick disease occurs due to the deficiency of sphingomyelinase. Affected children exhibit a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, reticular or nodular infiltration in the lungs, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option C- Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of β-Glucosidase. It commonly has a combination of growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells which have a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance resulting from the presence of intracytoplasmic substrate inclusions. The intelligence of the child is normal.

The below image shows Gaucher cells.

Option D- Tay-Sachs disease occurs due to a deficiency of hexosaminidase A. Affected children present with seizures, developmental delay, increased startle response, macrocephaly, and cherry-red spots in the eye. Hepatosplenomegaly is rare.

Cherry red spots are commonly seen in Tay-Sachs disease, Sandhoff disease, generalized gangliosidoses, Niemann-Pick disease, metachromatic leukodystrophy, etc

Below image- Cherry red spot

questions.text: What does the term folate trap refer to?
questions.solution:
The term folate trap refers to accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate with deficiency of tetrahydrofolate. It is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, vitamin B12 deficiency leads to folate deficiency.

Since vitamin B12 is also linked to regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, there is hyperhomocysteinemia as well. It increases the risk of atherosclerosis, hypertension and thrombosis.

questions.text: In a patient with jaundice which of the following tests can be used to determine serum bilirubin?
questions.solution:
Van den Bergh test can be used to determine the serum bilirubin level in a patient with jaundice.

Van den Bergh reaction is a colorimetric method to measure serum bilirubin. It is based on the formation of red-purple azodipyrroles when diazotized sulfanilic acid reacts with bilirubin.

Clinical condition Reaction with reagent Interpretation
Normal serum No reaction Negative
High conjugated bilirubin
Eg: Obstructive jaundice		 Reacts in the absence of methanol Direct positive
High unconjugated bilirubin
Eg: Hemolytic anemia		 Reacts in the presence of methanol Indirect positive
High conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin
Eg: Hepatic jaundice		 Reacts strongly both with and without methanol Biphasic reaction

 

Option A: Ehrlich's test is used to determine urinary and fecal urobilinogen.

Option C: Hay's test is used for bile salts in the urine.

Option D: Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of reducing sugars.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man came with complaints of long-standing arthralgia in the knee. On examination, bluish-black scleral patches were seen as shown. On further inquiry, he says that the urine turns black on exposure to air. Accumulation of which of the following compounds caused this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of alkaptonuria and the pathological discoloration shown in the image is ochronosis. Accumulation of the compound benzoquinone acetate has caused this condition.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, the enzyme which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme will lead to the accumulation of homogentisic acid that  oxidizes into benzoquinone acetate. Later, benzoquinone acetate polymerizes and binds to tissues (especially collagen fibres).

This oxidation process produces free radicals that cause tissue damage and incite inflammation. Additionally, the excess homogentisic acid is excreted in the urine. This results in the classical clinical features of alkaptonuria such as- 

  • Homogentisic aciduria- Black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 
  • Ochronosis- Bluish-black discoloration of tissues mostly involving ear cartilage, ocular tissue, the skin of the eyelids, forehead, cheeks, and hands, nail beds, and even deeper structures such as the larynx and tendons.
  • Arthropathy- Debilitating arthralgia or arthritis that may be seen after the fourth or fifth decade.

Other options-

Option B- Methyl malonyl-CoA is seen in urine (methylmalonic aciduria) due to deficiency of methylmalonyl Co A mutase which is a vitamin b12 dependent enzyme.

Option C- Increased orotic acid in the blood and urine is seen in ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency.

Option D- Sulfogalactosylceramide is accumulated in metachromatic leukodystrophy due to deficiency of Aryl-sulfatase A.

questions.text: After a diet rich in cholesterol, it is seen that the de novo synthesis of cholesterol in the liver decreases. Which of the following enzymes is involved in this?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the enzyme HMG CoA reductase is involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis in the body.

HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

Long-term regulation of cholesterol synthesis involves regulating the transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When there is sufficient cholesterol in the cell, transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase is suppressed, and there is decreased synthesis of cholesterol. 

When cholesterol is less, proteases in the Golgi bodies cleave a sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP). The protein which is then formed binds to a sterol regulatory element (SRE) on the DNA. This activates transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene which increases cholesterol synthesis.

Hormones that influence HMG reductase are:

  • Insulin and thyroxine increase the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Cortisol and glucagon decrease the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Statins inhibit the activity of HMG CoA reductase

Other options:

Option A: Acetoacetyl CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction that combines two molecules of acetyl-CoA condense forming acetoacetyl-CoA. This acetoacetyl-CoA enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway along with a molecule of acetyl-CoA.

Option B: HMG CoA lyase is involved in ketone body synthesis which converts HMG coA to acetoacetate. 

Option C: HMG CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction where the third molecule of acetyl CoA condenses with acetoacetyl CoA forming beta-hydroxy beta-methyl glutaryl CoA (HMG CoA).

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents with a red and pruritic rash on the sun-exposed areas of the body, along with a history of frequent falls, diarrhea, and dysentery. She was diagnosed with Hartnup disease. What causes these pellagra-like features in Hartnup disease?

choices.text: Excessive loss of niacin in urine

questions.solution:
Malabsorption of tryptophan leads to pellagra in Hartnup disease.

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan due to the mutation of the SLC6A19 gene on chromosome 5. As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced, and this manifests as pellagra, with dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

Clinical features include intermittent, reversible episodes affecting the skin and nervous system that are aggravated by sunlight, febrile illness, stress, and nutritional deficiency. Skin manifestations present after sun exposure and include erythematous, scaly patches, similar to pellagra. Neurologic manifestations include ataxia, tremor, mood disorder, depression, convulsions, and psychosis.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine, thus distinguishing it from pellagra. Urine may also contain indican, which is produced as a by-product of tryptophan metabolism. 

Casal’s necklace:

Niacin (Vitamin B3)

It is synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan. The active forms of niacin are nicotinic acid and nicotinamide. Nicotinamide is present in NAD and NADP, which are important for oxidation-reduction reactions and ADP ribosylation of proteins involved in the DNA repair mechanism.  

Deficiency of niacin causes pellagra. Important causes are as follows:

  • Dietary deficiencies of niacin or tryptophan
  • Hartnup disease- defective absorption of tryptophan
  • Carcinoid syndrome- enterochromaffin cells increase the production of 5-hydroxytryptamine. This decreases the production of niacin.

Excessive levels of niacin cause dilation of blood vessels, flushing, skin irritation, and liver damage.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals an infant with sparse and kinky hair. This, along with loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase. 

Menkes disease results from a deficiency of lysyl oxidase co-factor i.e copper. This is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A mutation: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B mutation: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoid syndrome excretes a large amount of a certain metabolite of serotonin in the urine. Which enzyme is involved in the production of this metabolite?
questions.solution:
In carcinoid syndrome, 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) is excreted in large amounts in the urine and the enzyme monoamine oxidase is responsible for its production.

A carcinoid tumor is a tumor of argentaffin cells that produces an excessive amount of serotonin and is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. Serotonin is a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism (as shown below).

Urinary metabolites of serotonin in patients with carcinoid syndrome include N-acetylserotonin glucuronide and 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid. 

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific for carcinoid tumors. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumors associated with carcinoid syndrome.

 Other options:

Option A: Aminotransferase is involved in the conversion of GABA to Succinate.

Option B: PLP-dependent amino acid decarboxylase is involved in the second step of the synthesis of serotonin, where 5-hydroxy tryptophan is decarboxylated to 5-hydroxy tryptamine/serotonin.

Option D: Tryptophan is first acted on by tryptophan hydroxylase in serotonin synthesis.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

Symptoms like secretory diarrhoea and valvular heart disease in carcinoid syndrome are due to serotonin.

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is the most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The reducing equivalent for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is NADPH. The most important source of NADPH is the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway.

The HMP shunt pathway, or pentose phosphate pathway, is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It generates NADPH and synthesizes ribose. NADP+ is hydrogenated to NADPH by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. Since the HMP shunt pathway and de novo fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. Thus, this forms the major source for NADPH for fatty acid synthesis. 

Other minor sources of NADPH are extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase and NADP malate dehydrogenase (malic enzyme).

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child has delayed developmental milestones and intellectual disability, with the following appearance (image A). On further examination, there is an enlarged tongue, cloudy cornea, and hepatomegaly. A radiograph of the hand is shown in image B. A girl born in their family also had similar symptoms and she died at 9 years of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Hurler syndrome. The child is 2 years of age and has coarse facial features like a depressed nasal bridge, thick lips, and an open mouth with protruded tongue. The radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpals and phalanges. These features along with severe developmental delay, cloudy cornea, hepatomegaly, and intellectual disability suggest that the child has Hurler syndrome.

It is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) I. It is caused due to deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

Patients usually present between 6-24 months of age. They have

  • Intellectual disability
  • Skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex- thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged diaphyses of the long bones, macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella
  • Cloudy cornea, glaucoma, retinal degeneration
  • Mixed hearing loss, etc

Other options

Option A- The Scheie syndrome is a milder form of MPS-I (MPS I-S ). The symptoms appear after 5 years of age and the diagnosis is made between 10-20 years. It is characterized by normal intelligence and stature, joint stiffness, aortic valve disease, corneal clouding, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option B- Hurler-Scheie syndrome is an intermediate between Hurler syndrome and Scheie syndrome. The onset of symptoms is between 3-8 years of age. They have mild or no intellectual dysfunction. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option D- Hunter syndrome is a type II MPS. It occurs due to the deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase. It shares the same features as type I MPS like coarse facial features, short stature, and dysostosis multiplex. However, there is no corneal clouding. It is the only MPS with X-linked recessive inheritance. So if a baby girl is affected in the family, it is less likely to be Hunter syndrome. All the other MPS are autosomal recessive.

questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis?
  1. Pyruvate carboxylase
  2. Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase
  3. Hexokinase
  4. Pyruvate kinase
  5. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
Pyruvate carboxylase and glucose-6-phosphatase are enzymes used in gluconeogenesis. These enzymes catalyze irreversible steps of gluconeogenesis.

Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis are 2 metabolic pathways in opposite directions (glucose being the substrate and product respectively). The reversible enzymes are common in both pathways. But a few reactions are not reversible in glycolysis. So a different pathway is used or a different enzyme is used by the body to make the reactions feasible.

At the start of gluconeogenesis, pyruvate carboxylase (Option 1) catalyzes the synthesis of oxaloacetate from pyruvate following which phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase converts it to phosphoenolpyruvate (not phosphoenol pyruvate kinase as in Option 2). Alternatively, at the end of glycolysis, the reverse of this reaction occurs in a single step catalyzed by pyruvate kinase (Option 4).

At the end of gluconeogenesis, glucose 6 phosphatase (Option 5) converts glucose-1-phosphate to free glucose and is an irreversible process. Alternatively, glycolysis starts with the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate by hexokinase (Option 3).

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following is not obtained from glycine?
questions.solution:
Nitric oxide is not a special product obtained from glycine.

Products obtained from glycine:

  • Creatine (from glycine, arginine, and methionine)
  • Heme (from succinyl CoA and glycine)
  • Glutathione (from glutamic acid, cysteine, and glycine)
  • C4, C5, and N7 of the purine ring structure

Note: Nitric oxide is a special product obtained from arginine.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient with short stature, disproportionate spine, barrel chest with pectus carinatum and a short neck came to the OPD. On evaluation, a diagnosis of lysosomal storage disorder is made. The glycosaminoglycan involved in the condition is a prominent component of which among the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucopolysaccharidoses IV and the glycosaminoglycan involved is chondroitin sulfate, which is a prominent component of cartilage.

It is composed of repeating units of N-acetyl galactosamine and glucuronic acid (GAG).

In this condition, the affected individuals survive into adulthood with normal faces and intellect. Short stature with a disproportionate spine, barrel chest with pectus carinatum, and short neck and limb abnormalities may be present.

Some important features of chondroitin sulfate are as follows:

  • The most abundant GAG in the body and is seen in the cartilage, CNS, and bone
  • They are located at sites of calcification in endochondral bone and are a major component of cartilage.
  • They are found in high amounts in the extracellular matrix of the central nervous system.

Other options:

Option A: Keratan sulfate I and II are the GAGs in the cornea. It is also found in cartilage and loose connective tissue. It is the only GAG that does not contain any uronic acid. The repeating units are galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine in beta linkage.

Option C: Heparan sulfate is the GAG present in the kidney basement membrane, where it plays a major role in determining the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration. It is also found in the skin. It contains repeating units of sulfated glucosamine and glucuronic acid.

Option D: Hyaluronic acid is the GAG present in synovial fluid. It is also found in skin, bone, cartilage, vitreous humor, and embryonic tissues. It contains repeating units of  N-acetyl glucosamine and glucuronic acid. It plays a role in morphogenesis and wound repair. The high concentrations of hyaluronic acid along with chondroitin sulfates in cartilage contribute to its compressibility.

The images below show the structure of the cartilage matrix containing glycosaminoglycans and the structure of aggrecan, a major proteoglycan present in cartilage.

questions.text: Which is the enzyme involved in the detoxification of ammonia in the brain?
questions.solution:
Glutamine synthetase is involved in the detoxification of ammonia in the brain. It combines ammonia with glutamate to form glutamine. It requires the hydrolysis of ATP.

Glutamine synthetase provides glutamine which serves as a carrier of nitrogen, carbon, and energy between organs. It also plays a major role in ammonia detoxification and in acid-base homeostasis.

The deficiency of glutamine synthetase in neonates results in severe brain damage, multiorgan failure, and death.

Other options:

Option A: Glutamate dehydrogenase is found in the liver mitochondria and deaminates glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate and ammonia.

Option C: Glutamate aminotransferase converts α-amino nitrogen to ammonia along with glutamate dehydrogenase. This is termed transdeamination.

Option D: Glutaminase is present in the liver and converts glutamine back to glutamate and ammonia, which is then detoxified to urea.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is incorrect regarding the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway?

choices.text: Ubiquitin binds to the protein by non–α-peptide bonds
Defect in this pathway leads to Angelman syndrome

questions.solution:
Ubiquitin mainly targets extracellular proteins is an incorrect statement. It mainly targets intracellular proteins for degradations.

The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is the pathway to degrade regulatory proteins with short half-lives, and abnormal or misfolded proteins present in the cytoplasm. This pathway requires ATP. Ubiquitin is a polypeptide present in all eukaryotic cells. It mainly targets the intracellular proteins. On identifying the target protein, it binds to it with the non–α-peptide bonds. The target protein may be bound by a single ubiquitin or multiple ubiquitin molecules. The tagged proteins are then degraded by proteasome.

Genetic disorders that result from the defect in the ubiquitin proteasome pathway include Angelman syndrome, autosomal recessive juvenile Parkinson disease, von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, and congenital polycythemia. 

For the discovery of ubiquitin-mediated protein degradation, Aaron Ciechanover and Avram Hershko of Israel and Irwin Rose of the United States were awarded the 2004 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother with complaints of self-biting his lips and nails. On examination, the child has delayed developmental milestones, spasticity, and dystonia. Nail findings are as shown in the image below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing self-mutilation and laboratory values showing hyperuricemia is most likely suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan disease.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine leading to increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP). Increased PRPP leads to increased purine synthesis, which is later degraded to uric acid. Increased hypoxanthine is also converted to uric acid.

The patients have intellectual disability, behaviors of self-injury like lip and finger biting, developmental delay, muscle dystonia, and extrapyramidal symptoms. 

Diagnosis is made by the elevated levels of uric acid and by HGPRT enzyme assay.

The image given below shows the metabolism of hypoxanthine and guanine by HGPRT.

Other options:

Option A: Autism mainly presents with problems in social communication and social interaction. They have poor verbal and non-verbal communication, absence of eye contact, repetitive behaviors like lining up toys or flipping objects, echolalia, etc. Intellectual impairment may or may not be present.

Option C: Patients with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) present with infections. Diarrhea, pneumonia, otitis media, sepsis, and cutaneous infections are common presentations. It is caused by various genetic mutations that lead to the absence of T and B-cell function. They have a low lymphocyte count.

Option D: Tourette’s disorder is characterized by sudden repetitive, non-rhythmic motor movements or sounds. They present with loud grunting or barking noises or shouting obscene words. Motor tics include tongue protrusion, sniffing, hopping, squatting, blinking, or nodding.

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Allopurinol
  • Febuxostat

questions.text:
What is the defective DNA repair mechanism in a patient with SCID?

(SCID - severe combined immunodeficiency)
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ). 

NHEJ is a predominant pathway for DNA double-stranded break repair. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, enhancing T and B cell diversity. Thus, NHEJ deficiency leads to combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. 

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is characterised by defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Genes involved are JAK3, RAG1, and IL-7R. Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria. 

X-linked SCID is the most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys. The genetic defect is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. In these patients, the thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells, resembling fetal thymus.

Autosomal recessive SCID is commonly caused by a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme. In these patients, the thymus contains remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles.

questions.text: FIGLU (Formiminoglutamic acid) excretion test is used in the assessment of the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:
FIGLU excretion test is used in the assessment of deficiency of Vitamin B9 (Folic acid).

FIGLU is converted to L-glutamate by the enzyme glutamate formimino transferase. This enzyme uses folate (vitamin B9). In Vitamin B9 deficiency, FIGLU accumulates in the body and is excreted in the urine.

Folic acid is a water-soluble vitamin, and its active form is tetrahydrofolate (THFA). It acts as a carrier of one-carbon groups. These one-carbon groups are attached either to the 5th, 10th, or both 5th and 10th nitrogen atoms of THFA.

The methyl group in N5-methyl THFA is used for the synthesis of active methionine. This takes part in transmethylation reactions required for the synthesis of choline, epinephrine, creatine, etc.

Folate deficiency results in

  • Reduced synthesis of DNA
  • Macrocytic anemia
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Neural tube defects in the fetus like spina bifida

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is used for the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine?
questions.solution:
Methionine in the form of S-adenosyl methionine is used during the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

questions.text: Calnexin is mainly involved in:

choices.text: Signaling release of calcium from endoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
Calnexin is a lectin chaperone that is involved in the folding of glycoproteins and it is located in the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum.

It binds to various proteins like the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens and plasma proteins. It makes the proteins stay within the endoplasmic reticulum until they are properly folded.

Calreticulin is another chaperone and calcium-binding protein, similar to calnexin but it is not membrane-bound.

questions.text:
An infant presents with poor feeding. He has tachycardia and tachypnoea along with enlarged tongue, hypotonia, skeletal muscle weakness, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum CK, AST, ALT, LDH, and urine glucose tetrasaccharide. Chest X-ray is done later as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CK-creatine kinase ; AST-aspartate aminotransferase ; ALT-alanine aminotransferase ; LDH-lactate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
From the above-given clinical scenario and the radiograph showing cardiomegaly (tachycardia and tachypnoea), Pompe's disease is the most likely diagnosis. The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and macroglossia. 

Pompe's disease (Type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiencyleading to lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells. It can appear within weeks or months after birth (infantile Pompe disease) or may appear late in juvenile, childhood, or adulthood disease (late-onset Pompe disease).

Laboratory findings will show elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Urine glucose tetrasaccharide, a glycogen breakdown metabolite, is a reliable biomarker for disease severity and treatment response.

Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for glycogen. It is diagnosed by detecting the decreased activity of the enzyme, α-1,4-glucosidase in the dried blood spots, leukocytes, blood mononuclear cells, muscle, or cultured skin fibroblasts.

Other options

Option A- Von Gierke disease occurs due to a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. Patients present commonly in 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Option C- McArdle disease occurs due to myophosphorylase deficiency leading to reduced ATP generation. The typical manifestations are myoglobinuria (secondary to rhabdomyolysis), muscle pain and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise. This is called the second wind phenomenon. Cardiomyopathy is not seen in this condition.

Option D- Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of muscle phosphofructokinase. The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria. There is no hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: The echocardiography report of a 35-year-old woman hailing from China indicates dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following conditions can explain her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is characteristic, and may also result in cardiomegaly, congestive cardiac failure and fulminant cardiogenic shock.

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of the 21st amino acid selenocysteine. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as:

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

questions.text: A dietician advising a patient regarding diet plans considers the specific dynamic action (SDA) values for proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates. Identify the correct sequence of SDA values in these substrates.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, option C represents the correct sequence of specific dynamic values (SDA) of proteins > lipids > carbohydrates.

Specific dynamic allowance (previously called the thermic effect of food): This refers to the increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food (diet-induced thermogenesis).

The values of SDA are

  • 30% for proteins: This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.
  • 15% for lipids, and 
  • 5% for carbohydrates.

Importance: It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein-rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling.

questions.text: A research fellow in biochemistry is studying the lac operon concept of gene regulation. He cultures E. coli. in a glucose-deficient and lactose-containing medium. Which of the following genes expressed in this condition helps convert lactose to galactose and glucose?
questions.solution:
The gene marked as 2 is the lac Z gene, which codes for β-galactosidase. This enzyme converts lactose to galactose and glucose.

Lac operon concept

Jacob and Monod studied the Lac operon model, which is the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium Escherichia coli. It is switched on when the bacteria have to utilize lactose for utilization. Otherwise, it is switched off. It contains the following genes:

  • lac I- it codes for the repressor protein
  • cAMP response element (CRE)- It is activated by binding the cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP). When activated, it increases the binding of RNA polymerase and increases gene expression.
  • Promoter site- It is the site where RNA polymerase binds the gene for transcription. 
  • Operator site- It is the site where repressor protein binds.
  • lac Z gene- It codes for β-Galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose to galactose and glucose. 
  • lac Y- It encodes for lactose permease, which increases the permeability of lactose into the cells.
  • lac A- It encodes for thiogalactoside transacetylase. 

For the working of Lac operon, the operator site should be free and the CRE site should be activated.

1. When glucose is present and lactose is absent- The bacteria utilize glucose. The lac I gene produces repressor protein, which binds to the operator site. Repressor-operator binding prevents the binding of RNA polymerase and, consequently, prevents transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into a polycistronic mRNA. 

In addition to this, excess glucose inhibits adenylyl cyclase. Therefore, the production of cAMP is reduced. Less cAMP means less cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP) binding to CRE. CRE is not activated, and lac operon is switched off.

2. When glucose is absent and lactose is present- Bacteria utilize lactose. The lactose inactivates the repressor protein. This prevents the binding of repressor protein to the operator site. The operator site is now free and RNA polymerase can start with the transcription. The low glucose level causes an increase in the adenylyl cyclase activity, and increases the cAMP levels. This increases the binding of CAP to CRE, which in turn activates the transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into polycistronic mRNA. 

3. When both glucose and lactose are present- The bacteria utilize glucose. The unused lactose binds to the repressor protein and renders it inactive. The operator site is free. However, the increased glucose level inhibits adenylyl cyclase and decreases the cAMP levels. Therefore, even though the operator site is free, CRE is not activated, which leads to the switching off of the lac operon.

questions.text: All of the following types of interactions cooperate in stabilizing the tertiary structures of globular proteins except _____.
questions.solution:
Peptide bonds are not involved in stabilizing tertiary structure of proteins. It forms the primary structure of proteins.

Interactions stabilizing tertiary structure of proteins are as follows:

  • Hydrophobic interactions
  • Hydrogen bonds
  • Ionic interactions
  • Disulphide bonds

Note:

Hydrogen bonds and Van der Waal interactions are involved in the formation of α helix (secondary structure).

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: CO2 is released in which of the following steps of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle?
questions.solution:
CO2 is released in steps B and C. Step B is the conversion of isocitrate to ketoglutarate which is catalyzed by isocitrate dehydrogenase. Step C is the conversion of ketoglutarate to succinate which is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. In these steps, there are releases of CO2 and conversion of NAD+ to NADH.

The tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA, Kreb's cycle, or citric acid cycle) refers to a sequence of reactions that take place in the mitochondria. It oxidizes acetyl-CoA to CO2 and reduces coenzymes that are reoxidized through the electron transport chain, with the formation of ATP. It is an aerobic pathway.

The TCA cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins. Most amino acids get metabolized either to acetyl CoA or to an intermediate of the cycle. It plays an important role in gluconeogenesis, lipogenesis, and the interconversion of amino acids. Since it functions in both oxidative as well as synthetic processes, it is an amphibolic pathway.

3 molecules of NADH and 1 molecule of FADH2 are produced for each molecule of acetyl-CoA that is catabolized during one turn of the TCA cycle. Each NADH gives approximately 2.5 ATP and FADH2 gives 1.5 ATP when they are reoxidized. In addition, 1 ATP (or GTP) is formed at the substrate level when succinyl CoA is converted to succinate. Thus, 10 ATP are generated for one turn of the TCA cycle (3x2.5 ATP from NADH +1.5 ATP from FADH2+1GTP).

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: You are a junior researcher studying about the properties of apoproteins.  Which of the following is the basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48?
questions.solution:
The basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48 is RNA editing.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is a result of RNA editing. The ApoB gene is transcribed into an mRNA that leads to the synthesis of 100 kDa protein in the liver, which is called apoB100. In the intestine, the same primary transcript is formed, but a cytidine deaminase converts a CAA codon in the mRNA into a UAA codon; thus codon for glutamine is changed to a termination codon. Thus 48kDa protein has resulted; this is apoB48.

DNA rearrangement, transposition and alternate splicing, do alter gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: A child with severe acute malnutrition is undergoing nutritional rehabilitation. During follow-up visits, he shows significant improvement in appetite, an adequate gain of weight, and a gradual increase in subcutaneous body fat. Activity of which of the following enzymes is responsible for the restoration of fat storage in this patient?
questions.solution:
The restoration of fat storage in a child undergoing nutritional rehabilitation, as evidenced by adequate weight gain and an increase in subcutaneous body fat, occurs with the help of acetyl CoA carboxylase.

With appropriate supplementation of nutrition, the child's body will gradually enter an anabolic phase. In the well fed state, there is an abundant supply of glucose, which is converted to pyruvate, which in turn is converted to acetyl CoA. Acetyl CoA is diverted into fatty acid synthesis, in which acetyl CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme. There is also a high insulin : glucagon ratio in the well fed state. This favors dephosphorylation (activation) of acetyl CoA carboxylase, resulting in increased fatty acid synthesis. The fatty acids thus formed (most commonly palmitoyl CoA) are esterified into triacylglycerols. This process is called lipogenesis. 

Note: The enzymes acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, thiolase, and carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I are involved in fatty acid oxidation and are inactive in the well-fed state.

questions.text: What is the percentage of cytosine in DNA if the percentage of thymine residues is 28%?
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in DNA will be 22%.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA, regardless of species,
A = T and G = C
Purines = Pyrimidines i.e. A+G = C+T.

In the question it is given that thymine is 28%, therefore adenine is also 28%. So, adenine + thymine = 56% and guanine + cytosine = 44%. Since guanine = cytosine, the percentage of cytosine = 44/2 = 22%.

questions.text: What percentage of cellular DNA is in mitochondria?
questions.solution:
1% of cellular DNA is in mitochondria. 

Human mitochondria contains 2 to 10 copies of a small circular ~16 kbp (kilo base pair) dsDNA molecule that makes up approximately 1% of total cellular DNA. Out of 37 genes in human mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), 22 genes codes for transfer RNAs, 2 for ribosomal RNAs, and 13 for proteins that play key roles in the respiratory chain. A feature unique to human mitochondrial mtDNA is maternal non-mendelian inheritance because all mitochondria are contributed by the ovum during zygote formation. Thus, mothers transmit mtDNA to all their offspring.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented with fatigue, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Investigations revealed hemoglobin levels of 9 g/dL and orotic acid crystalluria. Peripheral blood smear showed a large number of hypochromic macrocytes. Other red cells were microcytic and hypochromic. Serum folate, B12 levels, and blood ammonia levels appeared normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia with orotic acid crystalluria is consistent with orotic aciduria, a disorder of pyrimidine metabolism.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism. A defect in the enzyme uridine-5′-monophosphate (UMP) synthase in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. The condition is characterized by hypochromic megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Treatment includes, administration of uridine (100–200 mg/kg per day), which corrects anemia, reduces orotic acid excretion, and improves the other sequelae of the disorder.

Causes of megaloblastic anemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/partial gastrectomy, ileal resection, Crohn's disease
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency:
    • Acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia
    • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine)
    • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine).

Other options:
Option (A): B12 metabolic defect is unlikely since B12 and folate levels are normal.
Option (B): Urea cycle defect is also unlikely because the blood ammonia levels are normal.
Option (C): Purine metabolism disorders include gouty arthritis, adenosine deaminase deficiency, and purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency.

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constants:
questions.solution:
The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is expressed as Kcat/Km.

Kcat is the rate constant, which is the limiting rate of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction at saturation. It is given by Vmax divided by number of active sites of the enzyme. Km is the Michaelis-Menten constant, which is defined as the substrate concentration at which the initial velocity(Vi) is half the maximum velocity (Vmax/2).

For some enzymes, when a substrate (S) binds to the active site of the enzyme (E), and forms an enzyme-substrate complex (ES), the product is instantaneously formed. For such enzymes, the reaction of E+S→ES becomes the rate-limiting step. Its rate is determined on the rate of diffusion of the molecules in a solution. Hence, these enzymes are called diffusion-limited or catalytically perfect.

Examples of the catalytically perfect enzymes, where the catalytic efficiency reaches the diffusion limit of 108-109 M−1s−1:

  • Triosephosphate isomerase
  • Carbonic anhydrase
  • Acetylcholinesterase
  • Adenosine deaminase

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought with complaints of a fishy smell in his hands, feet, saliva, and urine. A urinalysis revealed the substance responsible for the odor, and a diagnosis of Fish odor syndrome was made. Which is the substance responsible for this characteristic body odor?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of fish odor syndrome, the characteristic odor is due to trimethylamine (TMA), which is released in sweat, urine, and breath.

Fish odor syndrome (trimethylaminuria) is an autosomal recessive disease. It is due to a deficiency of flavin-containing monooxygenase 3 (FMO3) which converts the amino acid, TMA (trimethylamine) to TMA-N-oxide (which is non-odorous) in the liver. TMA thus builds up in the body and is released in sweat, urine, and breath, giving off a strong odor of rotting fish from the body.

Patients present in childhood or early adulthood with halitosis or body odor (distinctive fishy odor). Patients suffer from psychosocial problems such as shame, anxiety, depression, etc. Diagnosis is based on high levels of excreted trimethylamine (TMA) in the patient's urine. 

Treatment involves avoiding foods containing choline such as egg, liver, peas, and soy products. A short course of antibiotics such as neomycin and metronidazole can be given which reduce the production of trimethylamine by the gut bacteria.

questions.text: You are a researcher studying the mechanism of action of statins which inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase by acting as a structural analog to its natural substrate. The Lineweaver Burk Plot for the interaction is given below. Which of the following is true about this type of inhibition?
questions.solution:
The given example of statin inhibiting cholesterol synthesis by acting on HMG-CoA reductase and the graph is a type of competitive inhibition. True about competitive inhibition is that the Km of the reaction increases.

Important parameters in a reaction include:

  • The affinity of the enzyme for its substrate is given by the Michaelis constant or Km. A low Km reflects a high affinity of the enzyme for substrate and vice versa. The value of Km is given by the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is equal to one-half Vmax. It does not change with changes in enzyme concentration. 
  • The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration.

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme binding site.

This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

Noncompetitive inhibition is by binding of inhibitors to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

Graph showing the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive and noncompetitive inhibition.

questions.text: Which among the following sentences about collagen is false?

choices.text: Collagen has a triple helical structure, forming a right-handed superhelix
Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity to collagen
Enzyme lysyl oxidase is defective in Menkes disease which contains copper as a cofactor
Marfan syndrome is due to mutation in gene encoding collagen

questions.solution:
Among the following sentences about collagen, the false statement is (option D). Marfan syndrome is due to a mutation in the gene encoding fibrillin-1 (not collagen).

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal world. It has a triple helical structure, forming a right-handed superhelix. A striking characteristic of collagen is the occurrence of glycine residues at every third position.

Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity on the collagen molecule. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues catalyzed by the enzyme prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, whose cofactors are ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and α-ketoglutarate.

Collagen is arranged in a quarter-staggered arrangement and further stabilized by covalent cross-links.

Menke disease is a progressive neurodegenerative condition with an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. It's caused by a defect in the ATP7A gene, leading to impaired intestinal copper absorption and transport, resulting in low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels. This affects the cross-linking of collagen by lysyl oxidase, which requires copper as a cofactor, leading to defective connective tissue formation.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: Which of the following chromatography techniques is correctly matched with its property used for separation?

choices.text: Hydrophobic interaction chromatography - selectivity for ligands
Ion exchange chromatography -  interactions with hydrophobic groups

questions.solution:
Gel filtration chromatography, also known as size exclusion chromatography separates proteins on the basis of their Stokes radii. Stokes radius is a measure of the effective volume a protein occupies in a free solution. It accounts for both the mass and the shape of the protein. 

The correctly matched chromatography techniques are:

  • Hydrophobic interaction chromatography - Interactions with hydrophobic groups
  • Gel filtration chromatography - Stokes radii
  • Ion exchange chromatography - Charge-charge interactions
  • Affinity chromatography - Selectivity for ligands 

Types of Chromatography:

1. Gel filtration chromatography: Proteins with large and small stokes radii are applied to the top of a gel filtration column. On entering the column, the small proteins enter pores in the stationary phase matrix (included proteins). During the mobile phase flowing down the column, they lag behind the large molecules, which get excluded (excluded proteins). Proteins thus emerge from a gel filtration column in descending order of their Stokes radii.

 

 2. Ion exchange chromatography: Proteins interact with the stationary phase by charge-charge interactions. Proteins with a net positive charge at a given pH will tightly adhere to negatively charged beads called cation exchangers. Proteins with a net negative charge will adhere to positively charged beads called anion exchangers. Nonadherent proteins flow through the matrix and are washed away.

Bound proteins are then selectively displaced by weakening charge-charge interactions. This is done by gradually raising the ionic strength of the mobile phase. It is shown in the image below.

3. Affinity chromatography is based on the high selectivity displayed by most proteins for their ligands. Enzymes are purified using immobilized substrates, products, coenzymes, or inhibitors. In theory, only proteins that interact with the immobilized ligand adhere. Bound proteins are then eluted either by competition with a free, soluble ligand or by disrupting protein-ligand interactions. It is shown in the image below.

4. Hydrophobic interaction chromatography separates proteins based on their tendency to associate with a stationary phase matrix coated with hydrophobic groups. Proteins with exposed hydrophobic surfaces adhere to the matrix via hydrophobic bonds that are enhanced by employing a mobile phase of high ionic strength. 

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text: An undernourished child is brought for consultation. You prescribe a mineral supplement that is absorbed by the mechanism shown in the image below. Identify the supplement.
questions.solution:
The given image shows iron absorption and transport from a duodenal enterocyte into the blood, hence the mineral supplement prescribed can be identified as an iron supplement.

The following image shows in detail, the absorption of iron from a duodenal enterocyte.

Dietary iron is available in two forms - heme and non-heme iron. Initially, the ferric non-heme iron is reduced to ferrous iron by duodenal cytochrome B (ferric reductase) or by vitamin C. The reduced ferrous iron is then transferred into the enterocyte by DMT 1 (divalent metal transporter). 

Heme iron moves into the cytoplasm with the help of transporters. Here, it is metabolized to release ferrous iron, which then follows the same pathway as non-heme iron.

Once inside the enterocyte, it can either get stored as ferritin or transferred across the basolateral membrane by ferroportin. In the plasma, iron is transported in the Fe3+ form bound to transferrin, which is a transport protein. Hephaestin is a ferroxidase that oxidizes Fe2+ to Fe3+ before it is transported.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby iron absorption too. Thus, iron is trapped in the intestinal cells which is eventually sloughed off. Hepcidin also inhibits the release of iron from macrophages by binding to ferroportin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis.

Iron is an important component of

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Cytochrome P450 groups of enzymes
  • Components of the electron transport chain
  • Ribonucleotide reductase

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate
